III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Eligibility requirements
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504
Section • (3) An independent living home, staffed and operated by
Description the child placing agency, must be clean, safe, and
appropriate to the needs of the youth it serves.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has a history of domestic violence with her partner and
resides with him. Youth A uses substances, spends time at
casinos and goes to parties. Foster care is aware of the dangers
Youth A is engaged in but has not changed placements.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed on 9/3/2024 via telephone. She
added that Youth A’s Holy Cross worker did reach out to Youth A
immediately and that Youth A’s most recent location is in Mt.
Pleasant, MI. She reported Youth A is no longer in danger and is
living with a girlfriend and the girlfriend’s mother. She discussed
Youth A’s DHHS investigation with her prior placement.
Several attempts were made to contact Youth A on 10/15/2024
and 11/6/2024. Contact information was left for Youth A to return
the telephone call. To date, there has been no response.
Chief Administrator (CA) of Holy Cross was interviewed on
9/5/2024, via video conference. She reported Youth A is in their
independent living program and the agency has no control over
the youth regarding their comings and goings. She said the
agency can only utilize the AWOL protocol when a youth is
missing from her placement and there isn’t much else that can be
completed. CA said she does know that Youth A and her child are
no longer living with her child’s father. She reported Youth A is
living in Mt. Pleasant and an active investigation is occurring with
her last placement on the child’s father’s home. CA reported
Youth A is in a safe environment and it appears that she is taking
care of her child and not using any type of substances. This
information is reported to her from the Independent Living
Specialist.
2

CA reported Youth A has been provided with many services from
Holy Cross. However, Youth A hasn’t always utilized these
services.
CA reported prior to Holy Cross taking case management of Youth
A, DHHS contacted them and inquired if Holy Cross would provide
services to a 17-year-old independent living youth who is living
with approved fictive kin. CA reported DHHS felt that Youth A was
not provided with enough services. CA reported she agreed to
take case management of Youth A and assigned Youth A to a
worker that fit well with Youth A. She reported this Independent
Living Specialist was a perfect fit and she knew she would go
above and beyond to help Youth A.
CA reported the agency provided numerous services to Youth A
when needed such as 6 jugs of distilled water for Youth A’s child,
$200 gift cards, transportation to medical appointments, referrals
to Corcoran house for an Independent Living Placement (ILP)
interview, hygiene products while Youth A was in the hospital and
baby products/clothing.
Independent Living Specialist (ILS)was interviewed on
11/6/2024, via telephone. Prior to the above date, attempted
telephone calls were made to interview ILS on 10/15/2024 and
10/17/2024. ILS reported that Youth A is doing well, and she no
longer has contact with her child’s father. She said Youth A is
living in Mt. Pleasant with her best friend and her best friend’s
mother. She reported Youth A is attending school and has one
class to complete before she can graduate from high school. ILS
reported she visits with Youth A monthly. Her last visit with Youth
A was 10/8/2024. She reported Youth A continues to be in a safe
environment with her child, her best friend and her best friend’s
mother. She reported Youth A is not using drugs or substances of
any kind to her knowledge. ILS reported her agency does not
require Youth A to take drug test/screen as this has not been an
issue with Youth A. She reported each time she visits with Youth
A, Youth A is coherent and focused and she observes Youth A’s
environment to be clean and safe.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
• Youth A’s case file in MiSACWIS was reviewed: Youth A
has been in thirteen placements, three has been rental
home apartments. Youth A is involved in community
resources such as Michigan Works, educational services,
3

parenting support, independent living resources such as
MYOI and Ronald McDonald.
• CA provided the following services that was offered to
Youth A however, she rejected and would not attend such
as virtual therapy, baby pantry, foster closet, a Michigan
works referral and transportation/ Alma Transit.
• Social Work contacts were reviewed:
8/30/2024 – ILS conducted a placement visit. Youth A is
staying with her friend and her friend’s mother. She has her
own room and her own bed. Background checks were left
to be completed on the girlfriend and girlfriend’s mother.
Youth A reports she has some of her belongs at her last
placement and has asked a friend to take her over there to
retrieve it. ILS recommended she bring a police escort.
Youth A requested ILS to help her by trying to get her gift
cards, an air conditioner, and living essentials for her and
child. Worker stated they would transport her to a foster
closet and look into the possibility of gift cards.
9/9/2024 – ILS conducted a placement visit. ILS
brought diapers for Youth A’s child and two packs of wipes.
Youth A's room was observed by ILS, and she had a full-
sized bed and a pack and play. The room and home were
appropriate.
10/8/2024 - ILS went to a home visit at Youth A's
Independent Living Placement. Youth A's room was a bit
messy, but there were no sanitary issues noticed. Youth A
was happy the foster closet was able to provide her child
with a swing, as well as bedding for her full-sized bed.
Youth A is still in need of a headboard, but the foster closet
is working on helping her get one. Youth A looked
physically well. She was clean and was dressed nicely.
More discussion centered around SNAP benefits, WIC,
Strickler Center and how to obtain additional food as well
as the baby pantry and how to go about getting diapers/
wipes/ formula and other baby products through them.
Analysis Youth A was not interviewed for this investigation as she was
contacted several times with messages left for returned contact,
but she did not return any calls. ILS, Youth A’s case worker
reported Youth A is in a safe environment that is clean and safe.
She said she visits with Youth A on a monthly basis, and this is
the least restrictive placement for Youth A. Youth A is an
Independent Living Youth whereby the agency has limited say in
the youth coming and going. ILS reported she has not observed
any kind of substances with Youth A. The agency is found in
compliance with this rule.
4

Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
